prompt: What's terminal ANSI code to print a hyperlink?
outputs:
In modern terminal emulators that support hyperlinks, you can use the following ANSI escape sequence to create a hyperlink:

```
\033]8;;https://example.com\033\\link text\033]8;;\033\\
```

Breaking it down:
- `\033]8;;` starts the hyperlink
- `https://example.com` is the URL
- `\033\\` closes the URL part
- `link text` is the text to display
- `\033]8;;\033\\` resets the hyperlink

Example in bash:
```bash
echo -e "\033]8;;https://www.example.com\033\\Click here\033]8;;\033\\"
```

Note that this works in modern terminals like:
- iTerm2
- Windows Terminal
- Recent versions of GNOME Terminal
- Kitty
- Some VSCode terminal windows

Not all terminals support this, so it's good to have a fallback display method.

In terminal ANSI codes, you can create a hyperlink using the following format:

```
\033]8;;https://example.com\033\\Link Text\033]8;;\033\\
```

Here's a breakdown:
- `\033]8;;` starts the hyperlink
- `https://example.com` is the URL
- `\033\\` closes the hyperlink definition
- `Link Text` is the text that will be clickable
- The final `\033]8;;\033\\` resets the hyperlink

Example in bash/shell script:

```bash
echo -e "\033]8;;https://www.example.com\033\\Click me\033]8;;\033\\"
```

This works in modern terminals like:
- iTerm2
- Windows Terminal
- Some modern Linux terminal emulators

Note: Hyperlink support varies by terminal, so test in your specific environment.

In modern terminal emulators that support ANSI hyperlinks, you can use the following format:

```
\033]8;;https://example.com\033\\Link Text\033]8;;\033\\
```

Breaking this down:
- `\033]8;;` starts the hyperlink
- `https://example.com` is the URL
- `\033\\` closes the URL part
- `Link Text` is the visible text
- `\033]8;;\033\\` resets the hyperlink

Example in different languages:

Bash:
```bash
echo -e "\033]8;;https://example.com\033\\Click here\033]8;;\033\\"
```

Python:
```python
print("\033]8;;https://example.com\033\\Click here\033]8;;\033\\")
```

Note: This works in modern terminals like iTerm2, GNOME Terminal, and newer versions of macOS Terminal, but not in all terminal emulators.

Here's the ANSI escape sequence to print a hyperlink in the terminal:

```
\033]8;;https://example.com\033\\Link Text\033]8;;\033\\
```

Breaking it down:
- `\033]8;;` starts the hyperlink
- `https://example.com` is the URL
- `\033\\` closes the URL part
- `Link Text` is the text to display
- `\033]8;;\033\\` resets the hyperlink

Example in different languages:

Bash:
```bash
echo -e "\033]8;;https://example.com\033\\Click here\033]8;;\033\\"
```

Python:
```python
print("\033]8;;https://example.com\033\\Click here\033]8;;\033\\")
```

Note:
- Works in modern terminals like iTerm2, Windows Terminal
- Not universally supported across all terminals
- Some terminals might require specific configuration

In ANSI escape sequences, you can create a hyperlink in the terminal using the following format:

```
\e]8;;https://www.example.com\e\\Link Text\e]8;;\e\\
```

Here's a breakdown:
- `\e]8;;` starts the hyperlink
- `https://www.example.com` is the URL
- `\e\\` closes the URL part
- `Link Text` is the text that will be clickable
- `\e]8;;\e\\` resets the hyperlink

In Python, you might use it like:
```python
print("\x1b]8;;https://www.example.com\x1b\\Click here\x1b]8;;\x1b\\")
```

Note: Hyperlink support depends on the terminal emulator. Modern terminals like iTerm2, GNOME Terminal, and Windows Terminal support this, while others may not.
